conclusion: The problem involves finding the acceleration of a particle from a velocity-time graph during the interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
In a v-t graph, the slope of the line represents the acceleration.
The graph is a straight line during the interval from 1 to 3 seconds.

premise: The graph is a straight line during the interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
conclusion: The acceleration is constant during that time.
The slope is given by the change in velocity divided by the change in time: a = Δv / Δt.
At t = 1 second, the velocity is 2 m/s.
At t = 3 seconds, the velocity is -2 m/s.

premise: At t = 1 second, the velocity is 2 m/s. At t = 3 seconds, the velocity is -2 m/s.
conclusion: The change in velocity, Δv, is -2 m/s - 2 m/s = -4 m/s.

premise: The time interval is from t = 1 second to t = 3 seconds.
conclusion: The change in time, Δt, is 3 seconds - 1 second = 2 seconds.
The acceleration a = Δv / Δt = -4 m/s / 2 s = -2 m/s².

premise: The velocity is decreasing and changing direction.
conclusion: The negative sign of acceleration indicates it is in the opposite direction to the initial motion.
The graph is a straight line from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds.

premise: The graph is a straight line from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds.
conclusion: The acceleration is indeed constant during that time.
The units of velocity are meters per second (m/s), and time is in seconds (s), so the acceleration units should be meters per second squared (m/s²).
The area under a v-t graph gives displacement, which isn't directly relevant to finding acceleration.
At t = 0, the velocity is 2 m/s, it stays at 2 m/s until t = 1 second, then decreases linearly to -2 m/s at t = 3 seconds.
